nodes.bodyText: You should add unit tests to check this behavior.
At this point you'll need to check if it is a JavaScript file and use msg.getResponseBody().toString() or if it's HTML and use the loop through script elements as you already have.

+

+import static org.hamcrest.Matchers.hasSize;
+import static org.junit.Assert.*;

nodes.bodyText:
This seems limited to Angular functions.
It could include eval() (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/eval) and likely functions from other major frameworks as well.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,9 @@
+# This file lists all dangerous JS functions being scanned for
+bypassSecurityTrustHtml
+bypassSecurityTrustScript
+bypassSecurityTrustStyle
+bypassSecurityTrustUrl
+bypassSecurityTrustResourceUrl
+trustAsHtml
+$eval
+$evalAsync

nodes.bodyText:
I added eval but I'm not too familiar with JS so I don't really know what dangerous functions from other frameworks are. I tried a little googling but only came across document.write() and even then I'm not too sure if it's dangerous in the same sense as these others (e.g. for XSS).
It's why I put the list as a file so it can easily be added to later on without any need to understand the scanner. If you have any good places for me to learn more I'm very willing :)

nodes.bodyText: I took a look at the PRs and am wondering whether to create an ExtensionPayloader in  pscanAlpha or import as a dependency the one from pscanrules? If I do the latter however I will instead then need to import into pscanrules my extension which would require an additional dependency import regardless, so I'm guessing I should go with the former?

nodes.bodyText: You should add a test for one of the functions that has a leading $ since that is a significant regex char.

While testing for this I realised that a search on $eval() using the regex pattern taken from the functions list $eval will fail but a match will be found if I used eval as the regex pattern instead. I have decided to amend the function list as such (refer to most recent commit).
Would like your opinion on whether this is the right direction to take, or whether I should relook at how my regex is formed, thanks!
I think that's ok (doing it without the leading $)

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                            0, // CWE Id - return 0 if no relevant one
          
          
            
                            749, // CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function
          
      
    
    
  

Or maybe: CWE-676: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function ?

Do we really feel this is Alert.RISK_MEDIUM we're not checking or suggesting that they're using user input. It's probably more realistic to put it as Alert.RISK_LOW or Alert.RISK_INFO and even Alert.CONFIDENCE_LOW
Mmm what about Alert.RISK_INFO and Alert.CONFIDENCE_MEDIUM? Since it's informational but a matching pattern is very likely a function name since we only check the js?

Mmm what about Alert.RISK_INFO and Alert.CONFIDENCE_MEDIUM? Since it's informational but a matching pattern is very likely a function name since we only check the js?

Okay nevermind after adding eval and taking another look I realised some of the words might give false positive to function names so I'll switch to CONFIDENCE_LOW and RISK_LOW :)
Sounds good.
This should be added to scanners.md
You'll need to modify the pscanrulesAlpha Messages.properties to setup these keys/values.
Ah okay gotcha, I had this nagging feeling I was forgetting something, thanks!
This is misleading, the method already initialises the patterns. Might be better to change to createPatterns and not assign there.
The evidence field should not contain extraneous characters, it should match exactly what was found in the HTTP message. (It shouldn't be needed anyway, it's just using the first find.)
The length check could be added to the first if statement.
Minimised files will/might not have newlines, we should ensure the line is not too big when adding to the evidence.
And in the case it has many lines it might lead too much memory usage, might be better to find the whole content and just get chunks around the function found?
You mean rather than initialise and iterate through lines, to just perform the pattern search on the raw text, i.e. remove call to split(\n)?
Right.
Same comment regarding the evidence (this might be better for the other info field too).
You mean split the call to Constant.messages.getString(MESSAGE_PREFIX + "otherinfo", pattern, line)); into a  separate variable to be displayed as other info rather than have it in the evidence?
Yeah, but we could still use part of the "line" as evidence.
I decided on removing the  "otherinfo" altogether as I didn't think it was necessary
Needs update.
Ideally this should be handled outside this method, otherwise the scanner will miss changes done to the payloads once the patterns is initialised.

Just wondering actually, how does the passive scan rule get notified when a new payload is uploaded? I didn't see an observer pattern anywhere and am largely basing my current payload implementation on what I could learn from other passive scan rules so I don't really understand it fully yet :")
There's no notification, the provider always returns the latest payloads. It would be useful to tell that to cache the Patterns, but that will require changes in the Custom Payloads add-on.
Hmm would it be possible then at every scan to check whether the payload has changed? Is there any built in change detection in Custom Payloads? If not I can just do a manual check
There isn't, it would have to be done here. But for the first iteration I'd not add the check, just create the Patterns each time.
We should provide the details here instead (if needed), in other alert descriptions we don't link to the issues.

nodes.bodyText: Is the regex part relevant? That seems to be an implementation detail, or you mean these are to be interpreted as regular expressions as well? If the former we should quote the strings when creating the Pattern otherwise we should catch the exception when the regular expression is invalid.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+# This file lists all dangerous JS functions being scanned for.
+# Searching is done via regex per whole word match on each line item [e.g. 'eval' will match with '$eval()'].

nodes.bodyText: Hmm I think we can omit the word "regex", I wasn't intending for user defined regex expressions in the payload. I just wanted to be more verbose with explaining how the searching would happen.

nodes.bodyText: I'd not add these, the test would fail anyway.
I don't quite get what you mean by this, are you referring to the test case or the specific assert method in this line?
These (this line and following) specific assertions.
Set
defaultPatterns? (And rename createPatterns to createDefaultPatterns?)
Worth extracting a method to have the same behaviour in both cases (also reduce some duplication).
This will include the \bs also, we can use the group() from the Matcher which would return just the name of the function.

This should be extracted to a method, same for file and payloads.
The line needs to be quoted (Pattern#quote) to handle special regular expressions chars (worth adding a test for the file and custom payloads).

During testing I noticed that it works so long as the special characters are not at the start or the end of the function names. For example, b$dFunction as an input pattern will match @b$dFunction() but $badFunction will not match $badFunction(). I'm thinking it should be fine as long as the behaviour is documented in the help page?
Alternatively I could just remove the word boundary \b during pattern compilation. I'm in favour of this implementation as it gives greater control to the user payload in exchange for a higher false positive rate which should be fine since the alert confidence is low.
Sounds good.
Was this meant to be patterns = new HashSet(defaultPatterns);? Otherwise it will change the defaultPatterns.
Yes it was sorry, thanks for catching that!
We should assert the evidence as well to make sure it's the expected.
This could be removed since it's being assigned later.
Should be singular, just adding one.
Could assert the evidence here too (and following test).
Tests revealed a problem with the html search logic. Added a check when cycling through HTML elements that if evidence is not empty to break.
We could also use a list? I doubt we'll have many duplications that we require a set.

I'd rather stick to a Set for scalability, I feel that it's a worthy tradeoff since the only downside over using a List is non-deterministic iteration which only affects testing. I addressed that in my latest commit so am thinking it should be fine?
What do you mean by scalability?
If the function list grows or if the payload gets very big.
That shouldn't be a problem, the file/payloads will not have millions of entries.
Gotcha, will switch to using a List then :)
